Low-cost catalysts based on Cu have emerged as promising catalysts for synthesizing ethanol from syngas, despite their limited selectivity to ethanol. This study investigates sulfur-modified Cu(100) surface for converting syngas to C2 oxygenates, and explores the intricate mechanism of C2 oxygenates formation from CO hydrogenation using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The findings indicate that the CH2 and CH3 are the most advantageous monomers over other CH x (x = 1–3) intermediates, surpassing methanol and methane formation. This result significantly differs from observations on the Cu(100) surface. For C2 oxygenates formation, the most effective pathway involves the insertion of CHO into CH3 or CHO via C–C to generate a stable intermediate CH3CHO and OHCCHO on the S-Cu(100) surface. Additionally, the examination of electrical and structural characteristics reveals a mild charge transfer between Cu and S, which enhances the catalytic performance for syngas to C2 oxygenates. Therefore, this work provides valuable insights into the role of sulfur-modified Cu(100) surface in enhancing the selectivity to C2 oxygenates. Introduction Ethanol (EtOH) presents itself as a versatile primary substance frequently employed in the synthesis of diverse commodities [1]. Microbial fermentation is the primary approach employed to generate EtOH [2]. While the conversion of cellulosic material shows great potential, it will require extensive research and development before it can be scaled up for commercial use [3]. Alternatively, to supplement current methodologies, the direct synthesis of EtOH from syngas could serve as a valuable technology [4,5]. Nonetheless, this catalytic method has limitations in terms of low yield and selectivity of EtOH. These limitations arise from the sluggish kinetics involved in the creation of C–C bonds and the swift expansion of the C2 intermediates [6]. Alcohols such as methanol [7,8], ethanol [9,10], and even higher alcohols [11,12] are commonly produced using Cu-based catalysts. The role of Cu surfaces in catalysis is substantial [13,14]. Various efforts have been made by our group and others to establish precise structure-activity relationships of Cu-based catalysts. Although Cu-based catalysts are easy to prepare and cost-effective, the main product of CO hydrogenation is methanol [15]. The hydrogenation of the CO bond is selectively facilitated by the Cu sites, while the hydrogenolysis of the C–C bond remains unaffected [16]. In the instance of Cu-based catalysts, the Cu metal surface readily combines with sulfur-containing species, resulting in the creation of the Cu surface that is adsorbed by sulfur [17,18]. However, the deactivation mechanism is often attributed to the significant adsorption capacity of sulfur, which covers or modifies the active sites of the catalyst [19,20]. Lisi and Cimino et al. conducted a research study that examined the impact of sulfur on the catalytic partial oxidation of CH4 using Rh-based catalysts. They found that the addition of H2S (8, 18, and 37 ppm) to the feed hindered both CH4 conversion and H2 selectivity, while CO selectivity remained unaffected by H2S concentration [21]. The findings suggest that the introduction of minute quantities of sulfide in the feed significantly alters the reaction. Some researchers suggest a linear relationship between sulfide content and its effect on the reaction, while others argue that the reaction remains relatively unchanged as sulfide content increases. However, this mechanism fails to explain why trace amounts of S species can occupy numerous active sites on both clean (where S atoms do not adhere to surfaces) and adsorb (where S atoms can spontaneously bind to surfaces) Cu surfaces. Consequently, the mechanism of Cu-based catalysts affected by S remains unknown. Further research in this area is necessary to address this issue. Cu-based catalytic reaction systems have been extensively studied for the synthesis of ethanol from syngas. The research on producing C2 oxygenates from syngas primarily focuses on two pathways: the formation of CH x (x = 1–3) [22–24] and the formation of C–C bond (C2 oxygenates) [25–27]. In our previous work, we successfully synthesized cubic Cu-based catalysts with six (100) exposed crystal planes [28]. However, the mechanism of sulfur modification on the Cu(100) surface remains poorly understood. Furthermore, Wu et al. developed Cu-S NSs, which are Cu nanowire sponges doped and adsorbed with sulfur on the surface, prepared through in situ electro reduction of copper sulfide nanowire arrays [29]. In this study, we investigated the S-Cu(100) catalyst using density functional theory. The S-Cu(100) catalyst was generated through the electrochemical reduction method mentioned in the literature [28,29]. We also explored an alternative method for producing C2 oxygenates and its by-products, including CH4, CH3OH, ethylene glycol (EG), and C2 hydrocarbons, using syngas and sulfur-modified copper catalysts. Our research holds significance for various applications of Cu-based catalysts because the sorption and desorption of sulfur on the Cu surface cannot be directly predicted from the standard thermodynamic database [30]. This paper not only enhances our understanding of the reaction mechanism on the S-Cu(100) catalyst but also provides insights into how sulfur influences the synthesis of C2 oxygenates from syngas. These findings can guide the development of high-performance catalysts in the future. Computational details Computational methods The Vienna Ab initio Simulation Program (VASP) package was used to perform DFT calculations in this study [31,32]. The plane-wave basis was employed to expand the electronic wave functions, with a cutoff energy of 400 eV. The interactions between electrons and ions, as well as the exchange-correlation energy, were accounted for using the projector-augmented wave (PAW) approach [33–35] and the generalized gradient approximation (GGA-PBE) [36], respectively, based on the functional proposed by Perdew–Burke-Ernzerh. We took into consideration the spin polarization in all of our DFT calculations. For the integration of k-space in our surface slab calculations, we utilized a (2 × 2 × 1) k-point mesh. In order to achieve fully optimized surface topologies and adsorption configurations, we aimed to reduce the Hellman-Feynman force acting on each ion to below 0.03 eV/Å. To determine the transition states of all elementary stages, we employed the Climbing-Image Nudged Elastic Band approach (CI-NEB) [37]. The validity of the transition state structure was confirmed through the dimer approach, where the forces were kept below 0.05 eV/Å via frequency analysis [38]. Computational models In this research, we investigate the lattice parameter of Cu in its pure bulk form. The obtained value, recorded as 3.645 Å, closely matches the experimental value of 3.620 Å [39]. To replicate the Cu(100) surface, a four-layer slab with a vacuum region of 15 Å was utilized. Each atomic layer consisted of sixteen Cu atoms, forming a 4 × 4 surface cell. In this study, S atom was used to modify the Cu(100) surface. The optimized structures of the S-Cu(100) surface and the sites of adsorption are depicted in Fig. 1 . In order to optimize the structure, we permitted relaxation of atom positions in the top two layers of the surface, while maintaining fixed positions for atoms in the bottom two layers [40]. Sulfur-containing compounds, especially hydrogen sulfide (H2S), almost always present in syngas from fossil energy [41], which affect the reaction processes [42].Iron-based catalysts require the sulfur content in syngas to be no more than 0.05 ppm. Furthermore, the total sulfur control index in methanol and coal-to-oil synthesis gas should not exceed 0.1 ppm. For the p(4 × 4) supercell, one sulfur atom was adsorbed on clean Cu(100) surface to model with surface sulfur coverage (θS) of 1/16 (approximately equal to 6 ppm). The same method was employed in the previous DFT calculation to investigate the adsorption of atomic sulfur on Fe(110) surface [43]. Therefore, the modified Cu catalyst with 6 ppm S content is much higher than the S content in the syngas. As a result, based on the above reasons, we chose the coverage of 1/16 ML surface sulfur to study the effect on C2 oxygenates formation over Cu(100) surface with sulfur modification. Results and discussion We investigated alternative reaction pathways on the S-Cu(100) surface to enhance our comprehension of the catalytic performance of the S-Cu(100) catalyst in the general process of C2 oxygenates synthesis. These pathways comprise two primary stages: activation of CO and growth of the carbon chain, as depicted in Scheme S1. CO hydrogenation and dissociation On the S-Cu(100) surface, the CO initial activation involves the direct dissociation process, with the assistance of H, leading to the creation of CHO or COH species (Fig. 2 and S1). In the initial state, the CO and H are absorbed at B and H sites, respectively, resulting in a decrease in the distance between the C and H atoms from 3.689 Å (CO + H) to 1.118 Å (CHO). CHO is produced by the route (CO + H → CHO). This process requires overcoming a reaction barrier of 81.8 kJ⋅mol−1, which is lower than the reaction barriers of CO → C + O (317.0 kJ⋅mol−1) and CO + H → COH (226.1 kJ⋅mol−1). It is also observed that the primary route for CO activation is CO + H → CHO, which is consistent with previous studies on Cu(100), S-Cu(111), Cu(111), Rh(111), and Rh(100) surfaces (Fig. 2 and S1) [22,44-48]. On the Cu(100), S-Cu(111), Cu(111), Rh(111), and Rh(100) surfaces, the energy barriers for synthesizing CHO are measured to be 100.9, 139.3, 105.8, 139.9, and 118.9 kJ⋅mol−1, respectively. These values all surpass the barrier (81.8 kJ⋅mol−1) observed on the S-Cu(100) surface. Therefore, CO activation on the S-Cu(100) surface is relatively easy (Fig. 2). Formation of CH x and its associated reactions The synthesis of CH x (x = 1–3) can be achieved through two pathways by starting with CHO: direct dissociation of CH x O assisted by H, or direct dissociation of CH x OH (x = 1–2). This section discusses the synthesis of CH, CH2, CH3, CH4, CH3OH, and C2 hydrocarbons. A detailed potential energy profile is shown in Figs. 3 and 4 and supplementary Fig. S2–S6. CH formation The adsorbed CO species on the stepped S-Cu(100) predominantly result in CHO as the primary intermediate, as shown in Table 1 . Therefore, the generation of CH from the starting states of CHO and CHO + H is attributed to the potential pathways associated with the elementary reactions (R4-R8) (Fig. 3). On the surface of S-Cu(100), the most efficient reaction pathways for the creation of CH involve CO and H reacting to form CHO and H, which subsequently combine to form CH + OH. To overcome a reaction barrier of 100.5 kJ mol−1. The energy barriers for synthesizing CH on S-Cu(111), Cu(111), and Rh(100) surfaces are 148.5, 106.9, 105.8, and 113.0 kJ⋅mol−1, respectively, which are higher than the barrier (100.5 kJ⋅mol−1) on the S-Cu(100) surface. However, the Cu(100) and Rh(111) surfaces exhibit a lower energy barrier for CH formation compared to the S-Cu(100) surface. On the other hand, CHO easily undergoes hydrogenation to form CH2O (32.5 kJ mol−1) on S-Cu(100) (CHO + H → CH2O, R7). These results demonstrate that CH2O, as opposed to CH species resulting from direct dissociation of CHO, dissociation of CHOH, or H-assisted dissociation of CHOH, serves as the main outcome of CHO hydrogenation. CH2 formation CHO hydrogenation is recommended for the formation of CH2O and CHOH. The progress to form CH2 species includes four types: CH2O dissociates, dissociates with H-assistance to generate CH2 and OH, CHOH dissociates, and CH2OH dissociates with H-assistance to generate CH2 and H2O (Fig. S3). CH2O dissociates with H-assistance to generate CH2 and OH on the S-Cu(100) surface. This process has high activation energies (11.7 kJ mol−1). In comparison to previously reported catalysts, such as Cu(100), Cu(111), S-Cu(111), Rh(111), and Rh(100), the S-Cu(100) catalyst exhibits a significantly lower activation barrier (11.7 kJ mol−1) for CH2 production via CH2OH dissociation, direct dissociation of CH2O to create CH2 and CH2O dissociates with H-assistance. Therefore, the pathway (CHO + H → CH2O, CH2O + H → CH2+ OH, R7, R12) primarily contributes to CH2 production. Additionally, the pathway with the lowest barrier (CH2O + H → CH3O, R9, 13.3 kJ mol−1) results in the formation of CH3O. These findings indicate that the mainspecies of CH2O hydrogenation are CH2 and CH3O species. CH3 formation CH3 is formed through a continuous process of hydrogenating CHO, leading to the generation of CH3O. CH3O species can undergo dissociation (CH3O → CH3 + O, 164.7 kJ mol−1) or CH3O then undergoes H-assisted dissociation to produce CH3 and OH (CH3O + H → CH3 + OH, 182.9 kJ mol−1) (Fig. S4 and Table 1). Significant evidence is presented in both Fig. 3 and S4, demonstrating that the preferred route for CH3 generation can be depicted as follows: CHO reacts with H to form CH2O, CH2O reacts with H to produce CH2 and OH, CH2 reacts with H to produce CH3. This pathway, with an energy change of 37.8 kJ mol−1, is highly favorable for CH3 production (R18). Additionally, compared to previously reported equivalent barriers of optimal reaction routes for CH3 formation on Cu(100), Cu(111), S-Cu(111), Rh(111), and Rh(100) catalysts, the activation barrier for CH3 production on the S-Cu(100) catalyst is significantly lower. Therefore, hydrogen-assisted CH2O dissociation and subsequent hydrogenation produce the CH3 species as the main intermediate, rather than CH3O through CH2O hydrogenation. To summarize, CH2 and CH3 are the primary CH x (x = 1–3) monomers found on the S-Cu(100) surface. The crucial step in the synthesis of CH2 entails the reaction of CH2O with H to produce CH2 and OH, accompanied by an energy barrier of 11.7 kJ mol−1. Similarly, the synthesis of CH3 involves a crucial stage where CH2 + H combine to form CH3, with an energy barrier of 37.8 kJ mol−1. CH3OH, CH4 and C2 hydrocarbons formation In the process of forming methanol (Fig. S5), the highest barrier is observed in the procedure of continuously hydrogenating CHO to produce methanol (103.2 kJ mol−1). However, the preferred pathway for methanol synthesis involves the steps CHO + H → CH2O + H → CH2O + H → CH3O + H → CH3OH (103.2 kJ mol−1). When it comes to methanol production on the surface of Cu(100), the reaction barrier is lower compared to S-Cu(100) catalyst (Fig. S5). Nevertheless, the formation of the by-product methanol is more easily observed on the S-Cu(100) surface when compared to Rh-based catalysts (Rh(100) and Rh(111) surfaces) (Fig. 4). In the formation of methane (Fig. S6), the maximum barrier is 83.3 kJ mol−1. The route for methane creation is as follows: CHO + H → CH2O, CH2O + H → CH2+OH, and then CH2 is hydrogenated to methane. The crucial step in methanol synthesis is CO + H → CHO (81.8 kJ mol−1) on the S-Cu(100) surface. Similarly, a crucial step in methane synthesis is CH3 + H → CH4 (83.3 kJ mol−1) on the S-Cu(100) surface. For S-Cu(111) surface, the route of CH4 formation is as follows: CO + H → CHO (139.3 kJ mol−1), CHO + H → CH2O (60.0 kJ mol−1), CH2O + H → CH2OH (107.6 kJ mol−1), CH2OH → CH2 +OH (124.6 kJ mol−1), CH2 + H → CH3 (66.2 kJ mol−1), and CH3 + H → CH4 (71.1 kJ mol−1) (Table S1). Furthermore, compared to other catalysts (Cu(100), Cu(111), S-Cu(111), Rh(100), and Rh(111) surfaces), the by-product methane is easily formed on the S-Cu(100) surface (Fig. 4). These results demonstrate that the production of CH2 and CH3 monomers is more advantageous than the production of methane and methanol. The formation of C2H4 (Fig. S6) occurs via the CHO + H → CH2O + H → CH2 + OH, CH2 + CH2 → C2H4 (17.5 kJ⋅mol−1) pathway. Conversely, C2H6 formation involves the route CHO + H → CH2O + H → CH2 + H → CH3, followed by the coupling of CH3 and CH3 to form C2H6 (155.2 kJ⋅mol−1). Comparing to the Cu(100) catalyst, it can be observed that C2H6 is inhibited on the S-Cu(100) catalyst, but the predominant C2 hydrocarbon is C2H4. Additionally, the Rh(100) surface easily generates the byproduct C2H6 (Fig. 4). Therefore, the path (CO + H → CHO) emerges as the decisive step governing the production of C2 hydrocarbons on the S-Cu(100) surface. In brief, the S-Cu(100) surface hinders the generation of by-products such as methanol and C2H6 in contrast to the Cu(100) surface, while encouraging the synthesis of the by-product methane. CH2 related reactions The reactions involving CH2 and CH3 on the S-Cu(100) surface are the main focus of this section, as indicated by the mentioned research. The activation energy required for the CH2 hydrogenation to CH3 is 37.8 kJ⋅mol−1 and involves three elementary reactions (Fig. S7). There are two pathways to produce C2 oxygenates by introducing CO or CHO into CH2. The first pathway is CH2 + CO → CH2CO (37.5 kJ⋅mol−1) for the C2 oxygenate (CH2CO) formation. The second pathway involves the CHO and CH2 coupling, resulting in the creation of a stable intermediate C2 oxygenate (CH2CHO) on the S-Cu(100) surface (CH2 + CHO → CH2CHO, 66.0 kJ mol−1). It is worth noting that while the C2 oxygenate (CH2CO) is easily formed on the S-Cu(100) surface (Fig. 5 ), the C2 oxygenate (CH2CHO) is easily formed on the Cu(111) surface, in comparison to other catalysts such as Rh(100), and Rh(111) surfaces. The findings presented in this study indicate that, among all CH2 reactions, the synthesis of CH3 is comparatively easier than CH2CHO and CH2CO on the S-Cu(100) surface. On the Cu(100) surface, the formation of CH2CHO and CH2CO exhibits lower reaction barriers compared to the formation of CH3CO (97.4 kJ mol−1). Additionally, these reactions are competitive in nature (Fig. 5). Reactions related to CH3 This segment concentrates on reactions that encompass CH3. According to the aforementioned research, the energy needed for the conversion of CH2 to CH3 through hydrogenation amounts to 37.8 kJ⋅mol−1. Fig. S8 illustrates the three elementary reactions associated with CH3. The formation of C2 oxygenates can occur through two pathways: CHO or CO insertion into CH3. The energy required to initiate the reaction pathway (CH3 + CO → CH3CO) is 111.2 kJ mol−1. In the subsequent reaction, the co-adsorption configuration of CHO and CH3 leads to the formation of a stable intermediate (CH3CHO) on the S-Cu(100) surface, through C–C coupling at the specific H site. This process has high activation energies (39.7 kJ mol−1). Based on the findings, it can be concluded that the synthesis of CH3CHO is relatively simpler compared to the formation of CH3CO in all CH3 reactions. Furthermore, the barriers for the formation of CH3CHO on Cu(100), Cu(111), Rh(111), and Rh(100) surfaces are comparatively lower compared to the barriers for CH3CO production(Fig. 5). Formation of C2 oxygenates through the coupling path of CO/CHO-CHO Studies on silica-supported Cu catalysts have indicated that achieving high activity and stability in the hydrogenation of oxalates to ethylene glycol (EG) requires strong metal-support interactions and excellent dispersion of Cu species [49–52]. The production of C2 oxygenates requires two crucial stages: the CO hydrogenation to CHO and the subsequent coupling reaction that combines CHO with CHO or CO on the Cu catalyst [53–55]. To investigate this, we initially focused on CHO coupling with CHO on the Cu(100) surface. The data in Table 2 demonstrate that coupling CHO molecules via C–C bonds generates a steady intermediate, OHCCHO, on the Cu(100) surface, with high activation energies (33.7 kJ mol−1). Subsequently, the intermediate OHCCHO undergoes hydrogenation to form EG with high activation energies (73.7 kJ mol−1). Hence, the facilitation of EG generation occurs on the Cu(100) surface. As observed in Fig. S9-S12, the CHO and CHO molecules combine to form the intermediate OHCCHO on the S-Cu(100) surface, requiring high activation energies of 24.3 kJ mol−1. This process exhibits higher favorability on the S-Cu(100) surface relative to the Cu(100) and Cu4/MoS2(001) surfaces. The reaction barriers for the latter two surfaces are 33.7 and 32.8 kJ mol−1, respectively [56]. In an alternative approach, the formation of C2 oxygenates occurs through the coupling reaction between CO and CHO (CO + CHO → OCCHO, 84.4 kJ mol−1). Additionally, the intermediate OHCCHO is continuously hydrogenated to form OHCHCH2OH, which can dissociate to produce CHCH2OH with an activation barrier of 80.8 kJ mol−1. Furthermore, the HOCCHO intermediate experiences a continuous process of hydrogenation, leading to the formation of EG while possessing significantly high activation energies (131.2 kJ mol−1). Thus, due to the presence of a lower activation barrier, CH2CO (37.5 kJ mol−1), CH2CHO (66.0 kJ mol−1), or CH3CHO (39.7 kJ mol−1), these C2 oxygenates are more frequently formed on the S-Cu(100) surface compared to the dissociation of OHCHCH2OH to form CHCH2OH (80.8 kJ mol−1) when CH2 or CH3 are inserted with CO or CHO. The production of ethylene glycol is also reduced on the S-Cu(100) catalyst compared to the Cu(100) catalyst (Table 2 and S2). The formation of ethanol through hydrogenation of C2 oxygenates In this section, our attention is directed towards the chemical process used to generate ethanol from C2 oxygenates, as illustrated in Fig. S9, S10 and S12. When commencing from CH2 species, there exists an activation energy barrier of 66.0 kJ mol−1 in the reaction (CH2 + CHO → CH2CHO). Additionally, we consider the process (CH2 + CO → CH2CO) which also has high activation energies (37.5 kJ mol−1). Our calculations demonstrate that CH2CO tends to be hydrogenated to CH3CO, with a high activation energy of 111.2 kJ mol−1. Compared to the formation of all C2 oxygenates, the C2 oxygenates (CH2CO and CH2CHO, 55.9 and 15.6 kJ mol−1) are easily formed on the Cu(111) surface [22]. Additionally, C2 oxygenates (CH2CO and CH2CHO, 37.5 and 60.0 kJ mol−1) are easily formed on the S-Cu(100) surface. The reaction (CH3 + CHO → CH3CHO, 39.7 kJ mol−1) starts from the CH3 species. Furthermore, we also take into account the process where CH3 combines with CO to generate CH3CO, which has high activation energies (111.2 kJ mol−1). Therefore, compared to the formation of CH3CO, the formation of CH3CHO is considered relatively simple. The most preferred C2 oxygenates due to the reaction barrier limiting the rate are CH2CO and CH3CHO. Based on the data provided, it is observed that the interaction between CHO and CH x is a more advantageous method for generating C2 oxygenates compared to the CO insertion into CH x . This finding aligns with the outcomes obtained from the Cu(111), Rh(100), and Rh(111) surfaces. Our examination of the S-Cu(100) surface suggests that the formation of CH3CHO requires significant activation energies (39.7 kJ mol−1). These energies are comparatively lower than those observed on the Cu(111) (49.6 kJ mol−1) and Cu(100) (41.9 kJ mol−1)surfaces. Additionally, the hydrogenation of CH3CHOH to produce ethanol necessitates overcoming a barrier with an activation energy of 205.6 kJ mol−1. In the case of CH2CO species, the hydrogenation of CH2CHO to yield ethanol occurs, followed by the formation of C2H5OH. These reactions possess activation energies of 205.6 . Furthermore, the OHCCHO pathway from OHCCHO species to ethanol exhibits high activation energies (131.2 kJ mol−1). Charge analysis of S-Cu(100) surface A microscopic perspective was employed to investigate the performance and structure of the Cu(100) surface with S modification. We computed the charge differential and Bader charge for the S-Cu(100) surface (Fig. 6 ). In order to gain deeper insights into the electronic properties of the S-Cu(100) surface, an examination of the discrepancy in charge density was conducted using a designated value of 0.004 e/Å3. The findings revealed a significant electron transfer between the S and Cu surface (Fig. 6a). Additionally, Bader charge analysis indicated an overall charge transfer of 0.63 e from Cu to S (Fig. 6b). Enhancing the catalytic performance of converting syngas to C2 oxygenates is achieved through the formation of a charge region on the S-Cu(100) surface. This study of electronic and structural properties reveals a moderate amount of charge transfer between S and Cu(100) surface. The role of S on the Cu(100) surface for syngas conversion Our investigation on the S-Cu(100) surface reveals that CO is hydrogenated to produce CHO intermediates on the S-Cu(100) surface, which aligns with previous findings on the Rh(100), Rh(111), Cu(100), and (111) surfaces, which exhibited high activation energies (118.9, 139.9, 100.9, and 105.8 kJ mol−1). Following the creation of intermediate CHO, we investigate the production process for promising substances including C2 oxygenates, ethanol, methanol, methane, and C2 hydrocarbons. The formation of CH2 and CH3 species proves to be more favorable compared to CH3OH and CH4. Consequently, we conclude that CH2 and CH3 species is of great importance in the continuous hydrogenation of ethanol, leading to the creation of CH2CO, CH2CHO, and CH3CHO after the insertion of CHO or CO. However, the production of CH4 through CH3 hydrogenation is hindered on the S-Cu(100) surface due to a high activation barrier (83.3 kJ mol−1). Our findings demonstrate that the sulfur-modified Cu(100) surface enhances the formation of C2 oxygenates from syngas, fosters the generation of CH2 and CH3 species, and enables the integration of CH2 and CH3 into CO or CHO. Compared to Cu(100) surface, S-Cu(100) surface simplifies the production of OHCCHO intermediate, leading to a novel route for generating C2 oxygenates. The findings indicate that sulfur modification of Cu(100) not only boosts the production of C2 oxygenates, but also lowers the energy barrier for the formation of CH2 and CH3. Additionally, sulfur facilitates the generation of CH2 or CH3 and CO or CHO insertion, while suppressing CH4 creation. Hence, the addition of sulfur promoter boosts the conversion of syngas to C2 oxygenates by employing the Cu-based catalyst (Fig. 7 ). Lian et al. studied effect of pre-adsorbed sulfur on CH x (x = 1–3) formation from syngas reaction over Cu(111) surface [45]. The effect of doping S atoms on surface geometric structures has been analyzed, where it was observed that the S atom did not participate in the reaction. Wu et al. conducted a study on the impact of surface sulfur on the hydrogenation of alkene. They found that the presence of sulfur on the surface made the further hydrogenation of alkene thermodynamically unfavorable [57]. This finding is crucial in understanding the high selectivity of alkenes over Cu-S NSs. Wang et al. confirmed that the spatial scale of Cu active sites on the Cu and S/Cu catalysts could be controlled by adjusting the supercell size of Cu catalyst and the surface S coverage of S/Cu catalyst, respectively, leading to different electronic and geometric effects, and therefore alter the catalytic performance [58]. They found that the doping of S did not participate in the reaction. Therefore, the doping of S atoms primarily influences the electronic properties and indicates the structure of the Cu surface, rather than directly participating in the reaction. Conclusions Using density functional theory, this study calculates the chemical process of synthesizing C2 oxygenates from syngas on the S-Cu(100) surface. The goal of this investigation is to analyze the impact of surface structure on catalytic efficiency and contrast the discrepancies in C2 oxygenates production between Cu(100) and S-Cu(100) surfaces. The existence of S on the surface of Cu(100) substantially diminishes the barrier of energy activation for CO, ultimately resulting in the selective separation of CH2O through hydrogenation to generate CH2. CH2 is then easily hydrogenated to produce CH3. Therefore, the synthesis of CH2 and CH3 is favored over CH3OH and CH4 on the S-Cu(100) surface. However, the predominant CH x species is CH3 on the Cu(100) surface. Similarly, the insertion of CHO into CH3 facilitates the formation of CH3CHO species. Consequently, the production of CH3CHO is an essential precursor for ethanol over the S-Cu(100) catalyst. The primary role of the S-Cu(100) surface in catalyzing the synthesis of ethanol is to provide the CH3CHO intermediate required for the formation of C2 oxygenates. The key function of the S-Cu(100) surface in facilitating the production of ethanol is to supply the essential CH3CHO intermediate necessary for the creation of C2 oxygenates. The analysis of both electronic and structural characteristics reveals that the moderate charge transfer between Cu and S further enhances the catalytic performance of the syngas to C2 oxygenates process. This finding highlights the crucial role of S as a promoter in significantly increasing the production of C2 oxygenates on the Cu-based catalyst. Hence, the inclusion of S substantially enhances the overall effectiveness of the syngas to C2 oxygenates conversion procedure. coredata.dc:description: Low-cost catalysts based on Cu have emerged as promising catalysts for synthesizing ethanol from syngas, despite their limited selectivity to ethanol. This study investigates sulfur-modified Cu(100) surface for converting syngas to C2 oxygenates, and explores the intricate mechanism of C2 oxygenates formation from CO hydrogenation using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The findings indicate that the CH2 and CH3 are the most advantageous monomers over other CH x (x = 1–3) intermediates, surpassing methanol and methane formation. This result significantly differs from observations on the Cu(100) surface. For C2 oxygenates formation, the most effective pathway involves the insertion of CHO into CH3 or CHO via C–C to generate a stable intermediate CH3CHO and OHCCHO on the S-Cu(100) surface. Additionally, the examination of electrical and structural characteristics reveals a mild charge transfer between Cu and S, which enhances the catalytic performance for syngas to C2 oxygenates. Therefore, this work provides valuable insights into the role of sulfur-modified Cu(100) surface in enhancing the selectivity to C2 oxygenates.
coredata.dc:title: Density functional theory study of Cu based catalysts with sulfur modification for the selective conversion of syngas to C2 oxygenates
